benchmark_details.name: Knowledge Corpus Error in Question Answering
benchmark_details.overview: This study introduces the concept of knowledge corpus error in open-domain question answering, empirically demonstrating that generated contexts can be more helpful than retrieved contexts from a conventional knowledge corpus. The paper shows that paraphrasing human-annotated gold contexts using large language models can enhance performance across multiple question-answering benchmarks.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To empirically observe the knowledge corpus error in question answering and demonstrate the effectiveness of generated contexts.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The study did not employ a retrieval setting and primarily focused on the analytic understanding of how generation can provide advantages over retrieval.

data.source: The data is derived from established question-answering benchmarks: NQ, HotPotQA, StrategyQA, and QASC, with specific context passages selected from these datasets.
data.size: NQ: 2532 samples, HotPotQA: 7405 samples, StrategyQA: 2290 samples, QASC: 926 samples
data.annotation: Human-annotated context passages were used for the experiments.

methods: Empirical testing using paraphrasing with LLMs
Performance comparison using two different reader models: GPT and Claude
methodology.calculation: Performance is calculated as the percentage of correctly answered questions among the total.
methodology.interpretation: An increase in performance indicates the effectiveness of paraphrased contexts over original gold contexts.
methodology.baseline_results: NQ: 40.9% exact match, HotPotQA: 36.3% exact match, StrategyQA: 54.6% accuracy.
methodology.validation: Results were validated through empirical testing across multiple question-answering benchmarks.
